'''Trauma-sensitive yoga''' (TSY) is defined as traditional [[yoga]] which has been adapted for work with individuals who have been affected by [[psychological trauma]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Nolan|first=C. R.|date=2016|title=Bending without breaking: a narrative review of trauma-sensitive yoga for women with PTSD|url=|journal=Complementary Therapies in Clinical Practice|volume=|pages=32-40|via=}}</ref> The goal of TSY is for [[Psychological trauma|trauma]] survivors to develop a greater sense of mind-body connection,<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Spinazzola|first=J.|last2=Rhodes|first2=A. M.|last3=Emerson|first3=D.|last4=Earle|first4=E.|last5=Monroe|first5=K.|date=2011|title=Application of yoga in residential treatment of traumatized youth|url=|journal=Journal of the American Psychiatric Nurses Association|volume=17|pages=431-444|via=}}</ref> ease their physiological experiences of trauma,<ref name=":1" /> gain a greater sense of ownership over their bodies,<ref name=":0" /> and augment their overall well-being.<ref name=":1" />
== Background == Trauma-sensitive yoga has been adapted from traditional yoga. Traditional [[yoga]] is a form of exercise conceptualized as a mind-body practice, which incorporates man forms and varies by class style. It typically includes techniques of body positioning, typically referred to as “physical postures”, and includes breathing exercises, [[mindfulness]], and [[meditation]].<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Nguyen-Feng|first=V. N.|last2=Clark|first2=C. J.|last3=Butler|first3=M. E.|date=2018|title=Yoga as an intervention for psychological symptoms following trauma: a systematic review and quantitative synthesis|url=|journal=Psychological Services|volume=April 2018|pages=|via=}}</ref><ref name=":4">{{Cite journal|last=Macy|first=R. J.|last2=Jones|first2=E.|last3=Graham|first3=L. M.|last4=Roach|first4=L.|date=2018|title=Yoga for trauma and related mental health problems: a meta-review with clinical and service recommendations|url=|journal=Trauma, Violence, and Abuse|volume=18|pages=35-57|via=}}</ref> Research has demonstrated that traditional yoga can reduce [[Stress (biology)|stress]],<ref name=":0" /> enhance physical health,<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Ross|first=Alyson|last2=Friedmann|first2=Erika|last3=Bevans|first3=Margaret|last4=Thomas|first4=Sue|date=August 2013|title=National survey of yoga practitioners: Mental and physical health benefits|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.ctim.2013.04.001|journal=Complementary Therapies in Medicine|volume=21|issue=4|pages=313–323|doi=10.1016/j.ctim.2013.04.001|issn=0965-2299|pmc=3721070|pmid=23876562}}</ref> and a heighten one's sense of self.<ref name=":6">{{Cite journal|last=Caplan|first=M.|last2=Portillo|first2=A.|last3=Seely|first3=L.|date=2013|title=Yoga Psychotherapy: the integration of western psychological theory and ancient yogic wisdom|url=|journal=The Journal of Transpersonal Psychology|volume=45|pages=139-158|via=}}</ref>
TSY was first established at the Trauma Center in Brookline, Massachusetts by David Emerson and colleagues. It was designed to promote an enhanced feeling of safety for individuals as they engage in an exercise that is focused on body awareness, which may otherwise be overwhelming for a traumatized population.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Emerson|first=D.|last2=Sharma|first2=R.|last3=Chaudhry|first3=S.|last4=Turner|first4=J.|date=2009|title=Trauma-sensitive yoga: principles, practice, and research|url=|journal=International Journal of Yoga Therapy|volume=19|pages=123-128|via=}}</ref> TSY addresses the need for a trauma-informed yoga practice that could identify and mitigate potentially triggering environmental and physiological circumstances,<ref name=":2" /><ref name=":5">{{Cite journal|last=Nguyen-Feng|first=V. N.|last2=Morrissette|first2=J.|last3=Lewis-Dmello|first3=A.|last4=Michel|first4=H.|last5=Anders|first5=D.|last6=Wagner|first6=C.|last7=Clark|first7=C. J.|date=2018|title=Trauma-sensitive yoga as an adjunctive mental health treatment for survivors of intimate partner violence: a qualitative examination|url=|journal=Spirituality in Clinical Practice|volume=|pages=1-17|via=}}</ref> while still providing the psychological and physical benefits that typical [[yoga]] practice offers.
TSY has been heavily formulated out of five core domains which are crucial to consider as they could produce adverse side effects under nonoptimal conditions among a traumatized population, potentially due to production of reminders of practitioners’ [[Psychological trauma|traumas]].<ref name=":5" /> The first core domain of TSY is the environment. TSY places greater emphasis on the environment as compared with traditional [[yoga]], as trauma survivors must feel that the space is welcoming, safe, and comfortable, in order to minimize overwhelming feelings of vulnerability.<ref name=":5" /> The second core domain of TSY is the physical exercise. While traditional yoga places a strong weight on achieving a particular posture, TSY highlights the importance of internal sensations in such postures to promote feelings of safety and self-acceptance.<ref name=":5" /> The third and fourth core domains are the hands-on adjustments and instructor style. Traditional yoga teachers are often directive and may provide hands-on adjustments to students' postures, whereas TSY instructors are encouraged to provide gentleness and space, and allow students to remain in control of their practice.<ref name=":5" /> Lastly, in contrast to traditional yoga instructors, TSY instructors pay particular attention to their directive language as traditional yoga verbiage could be a reminder of one's [[Psychological trauma|trauma]].<ref name=":5" />
== Rationale ==
=== Psychological trauma and the body === [[Psychological trauma]] occurs when an individual has experienced a traumatic event, which becomes lived and relived in the body and the mind.<ref name=":7">{{Cite journal|last=Tzu|first=G.|last2=Bannerman|first2=B.|date=2017|title=Transforming trauma into healing and being: a non-dual therapy approach|url=|journal=International Journal of Mental Health and Addiction|volume=15|pages=63-79|via=}}</ref><ref name=":8">{{Cite book|title=Trauma and the body: A sensorimotor approach to psychotherapy|last=Ogden|first=P.|last2=Minton|first2=K.|last3=Pain|first3=C.|publisher=W. W. W. Norton|year=2006|isbn=|location=New York|pages=}}</ref> Trauma can trigger a chronic stress response in the body,<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Christopher|first=Michael|date=March 2004|title=A broader view of trauma: A biopsychosocial-evolutionary view of the role of the traumatic stress response in the emergence of pathology and/or growth|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cpr.2003.12.003|journal=Clinical Psychology Review|volume=24|issue=1|pages=75–98|doi=10.1016/j.cpr.2003.12.003|issn=0272-7358}}</ref> which may manifest as an uncontrollable and constant state of heightened arousal and fear in the body.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Waking the tiger: Healing trauma|last=Levine|first=P. A.|publisher=North Atlantic Books|year=1997|isbn=|location=Berkeley, CA|pages=}}</ref> Those with a history of trauma may also interpret this chronic stress response as a threat to their sense of self and relation to the world.<ref name=":7" /><ref name=":8" /><ref>{{Cite book|title=Traumatic stress: The effects of overwhelming experience on mind, body, and society|last=van der Kolk|first=B. A.|last2=McFarlane|first2=A. C.|last3=van der Hart|first3=O.|publisher=The Guilford Press|year=2007|isbn=|location=New York|pages=417-440}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Theory and practice of counsellng and psychotherapy|last=Corey|first=G/|publisher=Brooks/Cole|year=2013|isbn=|edition=9|location=United States|pages=}}</ref> Some research suggests that traumatized individuals often have difficulty soothing their overactive internal sensations without relying on external stimuli, such as food, substances, or self-harm.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=van der Kolk|first=Bessel A.|date=2002-06-17|title=Posttraumatic Therapy in the Age of Neuroscience|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2Fabs%2F10.1080%2F10481881209348674|journal=Psychoanalytic Dialogues|language=en|volume=12|issue=3|pages=381–392|doi=10.1080/10481881209348674|issn=1048-1885}}</ref><ref name=":9">{{Cite journal|last=van der Kolk|first=B. A.|date=2006|title=Clinical implications of neuroscience research in PTSD|url=|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|volume=1071|pages=277-293|via=}}</ref> Therefore, psychological trauma is not only associated with psychological disorders such as [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD)]], [[Depression (mood)|depression]], and [[anxiety]],<ref name=":3" /> but also with somatic disorders.<ref name=":3" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Afari|first=Niloofar|last2=Ahumada|first2=Sandra M.|last3=Wright|first3=Lisa Johnson|last4=Mostoufi|first4=Sheeva|last5=Golnari|first5=Golnaz|last6=Reis|first6=Veronica|last7=Cuneo|first7=Jessica Gundy|date=January 2014|title=Psychological Trauma and Functional Somatic Syndromes|url=http://dx.doi.org/10.1097/PSY.0000000000000010|journal=Psychosomatic Medicine|language=en|volume=76|issue=1|pages=2–11|doi=10.1097/psy.0000000000000010|issn=0033-3174|pmc=3894419|pmid=24336429}}</ref>
Though most [[Evidence-based practice|evidence-based treatments]] focus on the psychological effects of trauma first and foremost,<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":7" /> attrition rates are still high, possibly due to heightened physiological arousal during the initial stages of [[exposure therapy]].<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":10">{{Cite journal|last=van der Kolk|first=B. A.|last2=Stone|first2=L.|last3=West|first3=J.|last4=Rhodes|first4=A.|last5=Emerson|first5=D.|last6=Suvak|first6=M.|last7=Spinazzola|first7=J.|date=2014|title=Yoga as an adjunctive treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: a randomized controlled trial|url=|journal=Journal of Clinical Psychiatry|volume=75|pages=1-7|via=}}</ref> Research has implicated [[Mind–body interventions|mind-body approaches]] as an alternative to traditional [[psychotherapy]], to allow traumatized individuals to reconnect with and identify their own physical sensations.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":9" /> [[Mind–body interventions|Mind-body approaches]] also allow those with a history of trauma to work through their somatic trauma memories and feel safe enough to emotionally and verbally process their traumatic memories.<ref name=":3" /><ref name=":9" /> Such approaches involve increasing awareness of, and attention to, body sensations, while emphasizing present-moment experience to counteract [[Dissociation (psychology)|dissociative]] responses.<ref name=":12">{{Cite journal|last=Pradhan|first=B.|last2=Kluewer|first2=J. D.|last3=Makani|first3=R.|last4=Parikh|first4=T.|date=2016|title=Nonconventional interventions for chronic post-traumatic stress disorder: ketamine, repetitive trans-cranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS), and alternative approaches|url=|journal=Journal of Trauma and Dissociation|volume=17|pages=35-54|via=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite book|title=Yoga and mindfulness based cognitive therapy--A clinical guide|last=Pradhan|first=B. K.|publisher=Springer International|year=2014|isbn=|location=Switzerland|pages=}}</ref> Finally, [[Mind–body interventions|mind-body approaches]] help the traumatized individual to nurture the body using internal resources.<ref name=":6" /> In this way, messages from the physical body may provide information for traumatized individuals about their identities and help individuals regain ownership over their internal responses.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berg|first=A. L.|last2=Sandahl|first2=C.|last3=Bullington|first3=J.|date=2010|title=Patients’ perspective of change processes in affect-focused body psychotherapy for generalised anxiety disorder|url=|journal=Body, Movement and Dance in Psychotherapy|volume=5|pages=151-169|via=}}</ref>
=== Physiological effects === The techniques of [[yoga]], in general, have been shown to alleviate effects on the body’s nervous system.<ref name=":6" /> The mindfulness and meditation aspect of [[yoga]] allows the mind to maintain objective awareness on the body’s physical sensations, while maintaining a state of calm.<ref name=":6" /><ref name=":13">{{Cite journal|last=Follette|first=Victoria|last2=Palm|first2=Kathleen M.|last3=Pearson|first3=Adria N.|date=March 2006|title=Mindfulness and trauma: implications for treatment|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10942-006-0025-2|journal=Journal of Rational-Emotive & Cognitive-Behavior Therapy|language=en|volume=24|issue=1|pages=45–61|doi=10.1007/s10942-006-0025-2|issn=0894-9085}}</ref> The aspect of yoga geared toward breath manipulation has been shown to play a role in enhanced capacity for [[Emotional self-regulation|emotion regulation]].<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Granath|first=Jens|last2=Ingvarsson|first2=Sara|last3=von Thiele|first3=Ulrica|last4=Lundberg|first4=Ulf|date=March 2006|title=Stress Management: A Randomized Study of Cognitive Behavioural Therapy and Yoga|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2Ffull%2F10.1080%2F16506070500401292|journal=Cognitive Behaviour Therapy|language=en|volume=35|issue=1|pages=3–10|doi=10.1080/16506070500401292|issn=1650-6073}}</ref><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Brown|first=R. P.|last2=Gerbarg|first2=P. L.|date=2009|title=Yoga breathing, meditation, and longevity|url=|journal=Annals of the New York Academy of Sciences|volume=1172|pages=54-62|via=}}</ref> Thus, [[yoga]] has been found to reduce the overall intensity of one’s stress response and improve one’s ability to self-sooth.<ref name=":6" /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Harper|first=J.|date=2010|title=Teaching Yoga in urban elementary schools|url=|journal=International Journal of Yoga Therapy|volume=1|pages=99-109|via=}}</ref>
Research has found that traditional yoga is associated with a reduction in physiological and somatic complaints often attributable to [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|PTSD]], such as pain and anxiety.<ref name=":11">{{Cite journal|last=West|first=J.|last2=Liang|first2=B.|last3=Spinazzola|first3=J.|date=2017|title=Trauma sensitive yoga as a complementary treatment for posttraumatic stress disorder: a qualitative descriptive analysis|url=|journal=International Journal of Stress Management|volume=24|pages=173-195|via=}}</ref> Research also suggests that yoga produces a number of /><ref>{{Cite journal|last=Berrol|first=Cynthia F.|date=1992|title=The neurophysiologic basis of the mind-body connection in dance/movement in the classroom and community|url=https://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/abs/10.1002/yd.44|journal=New Directions for Youth der Hart|first7=O.}}</ref>
== Key features == Trauma-sensitive yoga (TSY) is designed to begin gently, with a seated breathing exercise, followed by light movements.<ref name=":0" /> While adhering to the particular TSY conditions of the five core domains (i.e., physical environment, exercises, teaching style, adjustments, and language),<ref name=":5" /> the instructor guides the class through a series of physical postures at a level of difficulty fitting the advancement of the participants<ref name=":0" />. In each posture, instructors encourage students to observe their internal sensations, without judgment, and respond to them compassionately.<ref name=":1" /> Throughout TSY, participants are encouraged to make choices for themselves about what feels comfortable and safe in their bodies, and instructors spaciously invite students to modify any posture as needed.<ref name=":0" /> TSY class ends similarly to traditional yoga in a resting pose (“savasana”) wherein students lie face up on the floor with their arms wide and eyes closed.<ref name=":0" />
=== Safe-keeping === Certain conditions remain constant in TSY to ensure that participants have a felt sense of safety. Such conditions include consistency of room appearance and class structure, instructors' reminders to participants of where the exits are located, and bright lights so participants can see their surroundings.<ref name=":14" />
== Trauma-sensitive yoga for post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) ==
=== Mechanisms === Individuals who have experienced [[psychological trauma]] often view their internal body sensations as dangerous and foreign, and form destructive habits as a means of coping with their internal experiences.<ref name=":1" /> Throughout TSY, instructors strive to create an environment that feels both physically and emotionally safe for the participants, thereby facilitating a healing atmosphere for traumatic individuals.<ref name=":5" /> When students feel increased levels of safety and groundedness in their environment, they are said to be at an appropriate mid-range level of arousal for working with their [[Psychological trauma|traumas]] effectively.<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":8" /> Once TSY participants are at a mid-range level of arousal, they can learn to work with the physiological experiences of trauma in a more adaptive and less destructive manner.<ref name=":1" />
=== PTSD populations ===
==== Victims of interpersonal violence ==== Research suggests that trauma-sensitive yoga (TSY) is effective for improving the psychological symptoms for women who have survived [[Domestic violence|interpersonal violence]].<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":10" /> Improvements may include a reduction in [[Posttraumatic stress disorder|PTSD]] symptom severity,<ref name=":5" /><ref name=":14">{{Cite journal|last=Price|first=M.|last2=Spinazzola|first2=J.|last3=Musicaro|first3=R.|last4=Turner|first4=J.|last5=Suvak|first5=M.|last6=Emerson|first6=D.|last7=van der Kolk|first7=B.|date=2017|title=Effectiveness of an extended yoga treatment for women with chronic posttraumatic stress disorder|url=|journal=The Journal of Alternative and Complementary Medicine|volume=23|pages=300-309|quote=|via=}}</ref> reduction in [[Depression (mood)|depression]] symptom severity,<ref name=":5" /> and reduction in [[anxiety]] symptom severity.<ref name=":0" /> In addition to symptom alleviation, research has found that survivors of [[Domestic violence|interpersonal violence]] who engage in TSY have reported increased feelings of safety and agency,<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":10" /> higher [[self-esteem]] and [[self-compassion]], decreased feelings of isolation, greater feelings of relaxation, and a greater sense of agency over their own bodies, as compared with prior to TSY.<ref name=":11" />
== Current research == Currently, research has highlighted the importance of utilizing trauma-sensitive yoga (TSY) only as an alternative and complementary treatment to other [[Evidence-based practice|evidence-based treatments]] (e.g., [[psychotherapy]], medication) for trauma.<ref name=":4" /><ref name=":12" /> TSY classes are designed to differ from class to class, and thus efficacy has not been established.<ref name=":12" /> Research has suggested the use of TSY as a primer to individual psychotherapy, as a means of preparing and grounding the body before uncovering the stored traumatic memories,<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":4" /><ref name=":13" /> and establishing a traumatized individual’s buy-in for treatment.<ref name=":4" />
It may be important for consumers of TSY to consider the matter of [[confidentiality]] as it differs between TSY instructors and mental health professionals.<ref name=":5" /> Though TSY instructors are most often required to complete at least 200 hours of [[yoga]] instructor training with a [[Psychological trauma|trauma]] focus, confidentiality is typically not the focus of training.<ref name=":5" />

'''Wilhelm Jerusalem''' (October 11, 1854 in [[Drenitz]]/[[Drenic]] ([[Dřenice (Chrudim District)|Dřenice u Chrudimi]]), [[Kingdom of Bohemia|Bohemia]] – July 15, 1923 in [[Vienna]]) was an [[Austrians|Austrian]] [[Jewish]] [[philosopher]] and pedagogue.
==Biography== Jerusalem studied classical philosophy at the University of [[Prague]] and prepared a doctorate entitled "The Inscription of Sestos and Polybios". Until 1887 he was a teacher at grammar schools in Prague and Nikolsburg. In 1888 he became a member of the staff of teachers at the grammar school "k.k. Staatsgymnasium im VIII.Bezirk" (''Bundesgymnasium Wien 8'') in Vienna. In 1891 he was an outside lecturer at the University of Vienna. One of his interests was education, and he demanded a change of the educational system in the Austro-Hungarian monarchy. Another of his fields of interest was the education of minorities. He wrote a monograph about the education of the [[deafblind]]. In 1890 he published a psychological study about the deafblind [[Laura Bridgman]].
He is regarded as the discoverer of the literary talent of the deaf-blind writer [[Helen Keller]] and corresponded with her.<ref>Herbert Gantschacher ''Wilhelm Jerusalem – Helen Keller – Letters''. 2008; {{ISBN|978-3-9503173-0-5}} ARBOS-Edition, 2010-2012</ref> They never met personally. From scientific work about the deafblind he developed the Austrian direction of the philosophical method of "[[Pragmatism]]". In 1907 he translated [[William James]]'s "Pragmatism" into German. After World War I he became an associate professor of philosophy and educational theory at the University of Vienna . In 1919 he became one of the teachers of the "Schönbrunner Schule" ([[Schönbrunn School]]) which came about after the Vice Mayor of Vienna [[Max Winter (Vienna Vice Mayor)|Max Winter]] had obtained a considerable part of the Viennese [[Schönbrunn Palace]] to be used for the advancement of the education of young women, and a small number of men, to become educators and teachers.
In 1923, Jerusalem became a Professor of the University of Vienna. He died of a heart attack on 15 July 1923, in Vienna.
Among his students were the writer [[Stephan Hock]], the politician [[Karl Renner]], the composer [[Viktor Ullmann]], the poet [[Anton Wildgans]] and [[Otto Felix Kanitz]].

'''William Robin Thompson''' (June 29, 1887 - January 30, 1972) was a Canadian [[Entomology|entomologist]] and [[philosopher]]. ==Career== Thompson was born in [[London, Ontario]]. After studying biology at the [[University of Toronto]], he obtained a [[Bachelor of Science|B.S]] in 1909 and started working at the [[United States Department of Agriculture]]. During his employment there, he continued to study at [[Cornell University]] and received his master's degree in entomology in 1912.Israel, Giorgio; Gasca, Ana M. (2002). ''The Biology of Numbers: The Correspondence of Vito Volterra on Mathematical Biology''. Basel: Birkhauser Verlag. pp. 368-369. {{ISBN|978-3-0348-9447-0}} The following year, he resigned from the Department of Agriculture to conduct research at [[University of Cambridge]] during 1914-1915. He then pursued his research at the European Parasite Laboratory in 1919 and graduated in 1921 which a doctorate in zoology at [[University of Paris]]. In 1924 he obtained another doctorate, this time in philosophy at St. Maximin College in France.Thorpe, W. H. (1973). [http://rsbm.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/roybiogmem/19/655 ''William Robin Thompson, 1887-1972'']. ''[[Biographical Memoirs of Fellows of the Royal Society]]'' 19: 655-678. In 1928, Thompson left France and became assistant director of the Imperial Institute of Entomology in Britain, a service he held until 1947 when he returned to Canada. He became a professor at the Institute of Civil Service of Canada in 1949. Thompson was Director of the Commonwealth Institute of Biological Control in Ottawa (1946-1958).Coppel, H. C; Mertins, J. W. (1977). ''Biological Insect Pest Suppression''. [[Springer Publishing]]. p. 31. {{ISBN|978-3-642-66489-2}} He was appointed [[Fellow of the Royal Society]] in 1933. Thompson published about 150 articles in various scientific journals. Between 1947 and 1958 he was editor of the magazine ''[[The Canadian Entomologist]]''. He died in [[Ottawa]]. ==Evolution== Thompson was a [[Catholic Church|Catholic]] who held [[Alternatives to evolution by natural selection|anti-Darwinian]] views. He was influenced by the philosophical writings of [[Aristotle]] and [[Thomas Aquinas]]. He wrote the critical 16-page introduction for the 1956 Everyman Edition of Charles Darwin's ''[[The Origin of Species]]''.Hoppé, A. J. (1960). ''The Reader's Guide to Everyman's Library''. [[Everyman's Library|Dent]]. p. 95Kohler, Michèle; Kohler, Chris. (2009). ''The Origin of Species as a Book''. In [[Michael Ruse]], [[Robert J. Richards]]. (2009). ''The Cambridge Companion to the Origin of Species''. [[Cambridge University Press]]. p. 338. {{ISBN|978-0-521-87079-5}} His introduction was reprinted by the [[Evolution Protest Movement]] in 1967. Thompson rejected [[natural selection]]. Historian of science Sharon E. Kingsland has noted that:
"Thompson believed that all species possessed an essence, or form, in the strict Aristotelian sense, which could not be changed by material means. He had a strong aversion to the hypothesis that all adapted types had been produced by the random actions of mutation and natural selection. Such random processes might explain microevolution, but they could not explain macroevolution. Thompson could not suggest an alternative hypothesis for the ones he had rejected; he simply regarded evolution as an unsolved problem."Kingsland, Sharon E. (1995). ''Modeling Nature''. [[University of Chicago Press]]. pp. 136-142. {{ISBN|0-226-43728-0}}
Thompson also rejected [[theistic evolution]] and was critical of the ideas of [[Pierre Teilhard de Chardin]]. In his book ''Science and Common Sense'', he wrote that "there has been ''some'' evolution, but we cannot decide upon a ''priori'' principles how much. Natural science has no key to this problem."Stedman, Ralph E. (1938). ''Reviewed Work: Science and Common Sense: An Aristotelian Excursion by W. R. Thompson''. ''[[Philosophy (journal)|Philosophy]]'' 13 (52): 501-503. Biologist [[E. S. Russell]] noted that Thompson treated the philosophy of living organisms from an Aristotelian standpoint.Russell, E. S. (1938). ''Reviewed Work: Science and Common Sense : An Aristotelian Excursion by W. R. Thompson, Jacques Maritain''. ''Science Progress'' 33 (129): 193-194. ==Mathematical biology== After reading D'Arcy Wentworth Thompson's ''[[On Growth and Form]]'', he became interested in the possible application of [[Mathematical and theoretical biology|mathematics to biology]]. This view was unpopular at the time amongst American and Canadian biologists. In the 1920s he was influenced by the work of mathematician [[Vito Volterra]]. Thompson has been described as "one of the pioneers of mathematical modeling in ecology", but later became a staunch critic of it.Floyd, R. B; Sheppard, Andrew Walter; Joseph De Barro, Paul. (1996). ''Frontiers of Population Ecology''. CSIRO Publishing. p. 18 In the 1930s, Thompson radically changed his opinions about the use of mathematics in biology, believing the association was strongly negative. This was largely due to the work on [[population genetics]] by [[J. B. S. Haldane]] and [[Ronald Fisher]] which he believed was too abstract and devoid of common sense and empirical facts. Thompson was concerned that many of the arguments from mathematical biology were not based on biological observation. He believed that mathematical speculation should not replace the study of nature through laborious field research. Thompson outlined his views on mathematics, philosophy and science in his book ''Science and Common Sense: An Aristotelian Excursion'' (1937). ==Systematics== Thompson wrote papers on the [[species problem]] and [[systematics]]. In a 1952 paper he argued against the reality of [[species]] based on his opinion that the species taxon is an "abstraction" taken from the features of many individuals but species themselves are not "the individual or the collectivity of individuals."Hamilton, Andrew. (2014). ''The Evolution of Phylogenetic Systematics''.
